text.content: Study the Uniswap V2 Contract Source Code with Me -

title.plain_text: Study the Uniswap V2 Contract Source Code with Me -

title: Study the Uniswap V2 Contract Source Code with Me -
v2-pheripery
c
Uniswap v2 contract consists two compartment, one is
v2-periphery
a
https://github.com/Uniswap/v2-periphery
, the other one is
v2-core
a
https://github.com/Uniswap/v2-core
This post will study the contract code with you (mainly
UniswapV2Router02
c
in this post, later will also explore its front end code
I will use Visual Studio Code to explore the code
periphery is self self-explanatory, it serves as an entry point for us to interact
this is the project directory, and it looks like there is
interface
c
(which just interfaces that can be found on the description on the uniswap docs) and some shared libraries (i think they are just util functions that needs to be shared across real contract)
the migrator contract is just migrating v1 contract to v2, and
UniswapV2Router01.sol
c
is a stale contract that no longer in use, since
there are some low level bugs
a
https://docs.uniswap.org/protocol/V2/reference/smart-contracts/router-01
so our focus should be on
UniswapV2Router02.sol
c
, because from my experience, this is the contract we used the most
and i bet on that
UniswapV2Router02.sol
c
and migrator contract is the whitelisted contract for
v2-core
c
From the description of the
uniswap doc
a
https://docs.uniswap.org/protocol/V2/reference/smart-contracts/router-02
, it does not hold token balances

there’s functionality such as some state changing functions like adding liquidity, removing liquidity and swap tokens (from eth to token, token to token, token for eth) and some read only function such as get quote
and this also handles extra logic such as wrapping ETH, support fees on transfer and ERC712 that will not handled by
core-v2
c
, which separates the concern for these two projects
this contract includes the implementation of
IUniswapV2Router02
c
most of the function here is only a few lines, some logic are abstracted into the libraries
State variable, modifier, constructor and fallback
the first section defines two
immutable
c
variables which can be setup in the constructor which is the
factory
c
address in
v2-core
c
and the
WETH
c
address
the reason why this doesn’t use a constant here is that immutable could be assigned in construction time but constants can only be assigned at compiled time (can’t use constructor to assign them)
also, the reason why this doesn’t just use state variable is that using constants or immutable doesn’t take up storage space
this contract does not contain any other states
and there is an
ensure
c
modifier which ensure the transaction does not expire, which is the only modifer in the contract
the fallback function ensure only
WETH
c
contract can send ETH to the contract
this is an internal function which will be called by an external
addLiquidity
c
function, returns the amount of A and B when adding a pair of tokens in the liquidity pool
i added some comments to express my understanding
the question is, why is need to check minimum
since there might not be only one transaction to run this in a block, other people’s state transition might affect the amount of token supplied
note that the token needs to be approved to be transfer with
Router02
c
, as the
transfer
c
function to check if the contract has allowance
this function calls the
_addLiqudity
c
function, calculate the amount required and process the token transfer and minting
also add the liquidity, but for ETH
removing liquidity logic is more simple than adding liquidity, just need to burn the token according to the
liquidity
c
param, this will get back the amounts, and just need to check if it satisfy the minimum condition
note that this is a
public
c
function as it might also be called by other functions
withPermit
c
for all the function is that because LP token are basically implementing
EIP712
c
, so after the first time approve, a signature still needs to be submitted as permit in order it can be transferred
some tokens might implement transfer fee, this will function is for that and it will check how many balance that the token might get back
finally, another core function of swapping, we are half way through!
this is the core of swapping, see how this will route the tokens if there are more than 2 tokens!
this will swap two tokens and handles the first transfer, and this will handle the min output amount (remember when you type a input in uniswap, and it will output the largest output token possible)
this make sure
amountOut
c
is exact, and there will be a
amountInMax
c
requirement to swap the tokens
this will handles the wrapping/unwrapping ETH when doing the swap
Swap for tokens with fees on transfer
these functions will call
_swapSupportingFeeOnTransferTokens
c
instead of
_swap
c
, they are more or less the same and trivial to look into
this is a library that is called by
Router02
c
this function just returns whoever is smaller, this makes me know that
address
c
is also comparable
this function makes sure the token lp is determistic, there won’t be two token addresses because the order is decided
this will just return the pair lp address that is created by
create2
c
, although i am a little bit confuse how does it get the “init code hash”?
turns out this is the hash of the initcode of
UniswapV2Pair
c
ref
a
https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/89680/what-is-init-code-hash-and-how-is-it-calculated-used-in-defi-smart-contracts
first get the pair, then from pair address, fetch the reserve
since it’s a constant product AMM, so the relationship of amount and reserve is like this:
and we’ll skip the
getAmountIn
c
as they look more or less likely the same
and we’ll skip
getAmountsIn
c
as it is trivial to look into
SOOOO that’s all about the
periphery
c
! and i really look forward to
core
c
as there will be factory contract to look into!

description: turns what i’ve learnt about dev in words
